Thick lasting brown head. Brown color. Big roasted malt aroma. Tasty with lots of dark malts. No caramell sweetness. Dry taste and a fine balanced bitterness. Much roasted taste but no malt bitterness from the malts.

Dark brown with light red hint. Aroma is mild grass, cocoa and maybe a hint of coffee. Taste follows nose with a bite that hints of cinnamon.

660 ml bottle from Domus Birrae. Dark brown with some red tinges, difficult to see through, with a nice, creamy, fluffy and persistent light beige head. Grassy and herbal upfront, coffee beans and chocolate as follow. Slightly spicy (cinnamon) as well. Little metallic edge during the first sip quite bitter and dry, more coffee forward than the nose indicated. Slightly astringent, very mild sourness, lingering burnt caramel aftertaste. Average carbonation, light to medium body, slightly oily texture. Not my favourite Schwarz (even tho I suspect this is an old bottle), but a pleasent beer nonetheless.

Transfer from BA review on 8-31-12 - 
 Served on tap in a 10 oz chalice glass

 Appearance  Served a black beer with a one finger tan head. The head faded relatively quickly to leave a moderate amount of lacing.

 Smell  The aroma was of roasted malt with a good presence of chocolate and coffee. There was also a light caramel sweetness as well as some lighter more herbal hop aromas mixed within.

 Taste - The taste begins nice and roasty and remains that way much throughout. The flavors initially are of a coffee and chocolate flavor with a light amount of caramel sweetness (quite light). The caramel grows a bit in strength in the middle of the taste where it is met with the appearance of a light herbal hop flavor. The caramel however fades once again and the brew becomes even more dry toward the end. With the drying of the taste comes some notes of char and a nutty flavor, which when combined with the roasted coffee and dark chocolate from the start of the taste, leave a dark and dry flavor to linger on the tongue.

 Mouthfeel  The body of the beer was on the average side with the carbonation there as well. A bit of a thicker body may have suited the dark flavors slightly better, but for the style and dryness I think it was pretty good. 

 Overall  Roasty and tasty. While one I would not take as a session beer, it is one to have every once in a while.

[Tap] Opaque black pour with a small brown cap of head. Nose includes cocoa powder, coffee and some smoke. Dark roasted malts, bitter chocolate, licorice, toffee, hazelnut and mocha are featured in the surprisingly complex flavor profile. A mild earthy bitterness rounds it out. Clean and very drinkable. A really good beer.

Pours pitch black color with a nice 1-2 finger foamy tan head with good retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers.  Spotty foamy lacing on the glass, with a good amount of carbonation streaming up.  Aromas of chocolate, roasted malt, toffee, caramel, coffee, light char, grass, and herbal.  Very nice aromas with nice balance and complexity.  Taste of cocoa, coffee, roasted malt, caramel, toffee, toast, herbal, grass, and earth.  Lingering notes of cocoa, roasted malt, coffee, caramel, herbal, and grass on the finish for a bit.  Nice flavor balance, complexity, and robustness; no cloying flavors at all on the finish.  Medium-high carbonation and medium body; with a fairly creamy, chalky, and crisp mouthfeel that is nice.  Alcohol is well hidden with zero warming noticed after the finish.  Overall this is an excellent schwarzbier!  Very robust and balanced roasted flavors; extremely smooth and crisp to drink.  Really enjoyed this one.

Bottle.  Pours dark with a slick of tan foam.  Aroma is heavy roast with a bit of char and some light sweet malt on the finish.  Taste is dominated by roasted malt with char, perhaps slight ash, coffee rinds, a subtle and pleasant sweet malt presence about mid-palate, and a very clean finish.  Mouthfeel is somehow crisp up front but creamy into the finish.  Damn fine beer with a ton of flavor for 5% ABV.  Impressed.

Pitch black, small tan head. Licorice, cream, coffee. Very rich aroma for the abv. Decent feel feel, light tintling. Surprisingly bitter. Some citric taste too. Hangs in the mouth long time. Very well made. (At the De Molen tasting)
Bottle @ 2nd Tuesday tasting @ De Molen. Aroma is big liquorice, roast, some spicy notes. Flavour is roast, a bit watery, some liquorice, quite bitter and dry. Nice.

Bottle at de molen tasting.  Dark brown, almost black pour with a ring tan head.  Aroma is strong burnt malts, a little chocolate.  Flavour dominated by burnt malt, some whiskey, chocolate, toffee, and medium bitterness.  Medium bodied with soft carbonation.
Sample at the molen tasting.Decent off white head.  Very deep black pour.  Lovely taste. A bit watery and very bitter but good brew.

22 oz. bottle from Table and Vine. Liquid is real deep brown only some red highlights when held up to light. Plenty of carbonation producing thick tan head in the lager glass. Good retention and lace until conclusion; leaving some foam at the bottom of my glass. Roasted and chocolate malt nose. The roasted malts with the addition of light smoke and a Euro like hop; gives this an authentic German feel. Light bitterness in the finish. Slightly lingering roast. For me its a great style of beer when you want roasted and chocolate flavors and dont want a thick and full-bodied stout or porter. Port Brewing did a great job with this style. If you are unfamiliar with the style, try a few and include this one!

(bottle).  Dark brown complexion and tan head.  The flavor is a mellow, well roasted malt.  Nice palate.   

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
251011: Black colored beer with a nice brown foam. Lovely toasted taste. Lacks a little fullness.
In bottle at The BrewDog Bar, Edinburgh. A black beer with a decent tan head. Aroma of caramel, chocolate and Weetabix malt. Similar flavours with moderate carbonation and a foamy mouth-feel.

Draft at Monks. Poured near black with a big dark tan head. Tastes like dark roasted coffee. Some sweet malt notes but the burned coffee flavors dominate. Bit creamy when cold but ends up way too thin. Smooth dry finish.

Dark and toasty malts compliment the smooth hops of this black lager. A light refreshing mouthfeel make this a good summer session lager

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Oh, whats this? Oh, its a lager. No matter, I enjoy Port Brewing, regardless. Oh... Okay, I dont mean to be harsh about it, I did enjoy it, just expected something else. Poured a dark, with a soda like visual and consistency. Aroma was malty, with notes of smoke, roasted malts. Flavor was caramel, malty, with a touch of hops. Overall its okay.

0.65l bottle from beermerchants.com This one pours a near black body with a really big and quite special looking massive chocolate head. It has kinda big bubbles at the bottom, the they get smaller and denser at the middle before its almost creamy at the top! Looks amazing. Anyhow, it smells like a well roasted cup of cold coffee with a nice hoppy and a mild acidic hint. Its well carbonated with a somewhat thin and quite slick texture. It tastes like a good schwarz: Light hoppy, roasted - almost burned malts, cold and thin coffee and there is also a subtle acidic tone. Lingering roasty-cold coffee with some ashy flavors in the aftertaste. Nice flavors and a good schwarz, but like so many of them, just almost for me. 22.04.2012

Super dark brown pour with a thin tan head.  Lots of coffee-like roasted malt and charred bread crust in the nose.  The aroma also has a nice umami quality, similar to what I find in the oyster stouts that I like.  Taste is very dry, just slightly astringent, and the charred toast aspect is accompanied by a twangy lager note.  Light-medium body, ample carb, and it feels like the roasted malt dryness provides the bitterness instead of the hops.  Something about this just doesnt quite do it for me, but this is a nice beer.

Location/Date:Bottle on April 25th, 2012.
Appearance: Pours dark black with white head
Aroma: Aroma is really very roasty./
Taste: Light bitterness, roastiness, smokey.
Palate:Lighter body.
Summary: I liked this beer. It is lighter than it looks, and the smokiness is a nice hcange of pace.

Super roasty and super easy to drink.  Pours dark with no head, mild to medium carbonation, no lacing.  It looks almost translucent black it is such a dark brown.  Palate is heavy roasted nuts, smoke.  Finish is quick and clean.  Good change of pace, enjoyable.
Bottle. Dark brown pour, coffee head. Dominant roasted malts, reminiscent of a black ipa, some chocolate. Medium body, medium flavor duration, medium carbonation.
Dark color, dark rich head, extremely light however. Very much a shock to my tastebuds.

Color: Black
Aroma:Roasted barley, some coffee
Body:Initially sweet breadish flavor moving over to burnt coffee and a hint of chocolate. 
Finish:Roasted flavors continue with some remaining sweetness. 
Over-all/Mouth-feel:Medium, medium to medium-high carbonation.

Bottle.Pours reddish dark brown with a beige head.Aroma of roasted malt, dark berries, grains and some smoked notes. Flavor is sweet and roasted with some chocolate, caramel, and yeast.Medium body, average carbonation.

Bottle, 22oz. It forms a dense, almost creamy dark beige head over a clear looking almost black body, with a reddish hue. The aroma is roasted and lightly berry-ish, with a touch of dark chocolate and coffee. Burnt flavor with coffee and dark chocolate, some sweetness too. A bit too much actually, at least if it wants to be a true schwarzbier. Medium body, a bit heavy on the carbonation. Lasting roasted finish. A nice beer, but sort of not living up to what expected. 120324

Bottle 650ml @ yngwie
Pours black with a tan head. Aroma has notes of roasted malt, chocolate and caramel. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter. Body is light to medium, texture is thin to oily, carbonation is soft.

Caramalty aroma.  Poured a darker brown in color.  Flavor is a smokey lager with a bit of a roast finish.

Notes:  GABF 09

Poured from a draft into a pint glass at KnB Wine Cellars on March 21, 2012 in San Diego. Color was black. Had about two fingers of head. Brown coffee lacing on the top that turned into a slowly fading circle with blank black spots in the middle. Light film on the sides, but still there.

Smell was coffee heavy. Real dark chocolate malts. Expected, but decent nonetheless. 

Tasted similar to the nose. Coffee and real dark chocolate malts. Kind of like the kind I hated when I was a kid. Very smooth though.

Full body. Lively (above average) carbonation. Smooth, creamy texture. Smooth rules the day here. 

I really liked this beer. Just a smooth and consistent easy drinking beer.

from Erzbierschof.ch - black beer under a solid long lasting dark beige foam; nice lacework; very roasted aroma of mocha and ashes; a respectable malt backbone and a fair tart bitterness; very tasty palate; long and dry toasted coffeish aftertaste with more kingering notes of ashes - lot of character

22 oz bottle.  Pours dark brown with a thick head.  Thin aroma, but you can smell the roasted malts.  Flavor is a forgettable, but does have a nice dark malt side to it that is mildly sweet.  Light mouthfeel.

A - Pours a very dark black color with just a hint of brown and a finger of frothy and almost creamy chocolate colored head. The head fades down very slowly leaving behind some nice lace.

S - The aroma is a mix of roasted chocolate and a touch of coffee. There is a bit of sweetness with just a touch of smoke.

T - Starts off with a mix of roasted chocolate malts with a touch of smoke and some burnt flavor. There is just a bit of sweetness as well. Through the middle, some coffee flavor comes through alongside a bit more smoke. The finish is a mix of chocolate, bitter coffee, smoke, and a bit of cream sweetness.

M - Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Feels smooth with a roasted and lightly smoky feeling.

D - Very drinkable. Nice balance of coffee and chocolate flavors with some complexity added with the smoke flavor.

Black pour with tan head.  Nose mostly of dark malt and maybe a little chocolate.  Taste follows the nose with a nice crisp finish.  Mild hop profile.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Love me some dark lagers.  Really great roasty aroma with a delicate caramel malt profile.  Smooth and quaffable.  Really a great session beer.
Delicious roasty lager here. Like those Baltic porters. Thin body, this one is tasty, is it bad that I like port a lot more than lost abbey?

Crisp and refreshing, very strong roasted malt flavor. Not hoppy nor very aromatic, dark porter color.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Black as night with a tan head showing good retention and lacing. Rich roasted nuts on the nose. Balanced and light to medium bodied. This is a choice 10 times out of 10 over stuff like Guinness if Im looking for a lighter bodied dark beer.
On draft at iron abbey. This is really good, coffee dominates the aroma and taste, along with roasted malts, and a bit of chocolate. Excellent.

World class example of the style. Pours black with some brown hues along the edges. Foam is prominent with a light tan color. Beautiful beer. Aromas are roast, cocoa, coffee, and a dash of herbal hops. Taste is fantastic. Dark malts are full up front, the cocoa and roasted coffee dominate, middle is full of a woody mineral like flavor, and the finish is roast, hops, but finishes so incredibly clean. All the best aspects of a well made beer with all the positives aspects of a lager. The clean finish really accentuates the flavors found here. Well carbonated and super drinkable. A damn fine beer.

Pour is a very deep shade of brown, nearing black with almost no head at all. Nose is very roasty, almost like that or a porter. Taste is deep malty, and roasty, almost like a smoked porter again. Rather thin on the tongue.

Poured into a Samuel Smiths English pint glass from a 22 ounce bottle bottled on 12-20-2011.

A: Deep, almost opaque, garnet with light only visible through the edges. Theres a dense 1.5 finger tan rocky head.

S: Very simple with a great roasty smell to it. Very simple, but great smelling.

T: Like the smell this is very one dimensional with the roasted malts coming through strong. Its a bit watery up front, but the roasty body comes in quick and stays to the finish.

M: Medium to full bodied with light carbonation.

O: I really enjoy this beer, its simple and very easy to drink. Im glad Port Brewing finally came to New Jersey so I can enjoy brews like this.

Serving: 22 oz. bottle.  Pours black with a small head.  The nose is very roasty.  The flavor has bits of chocolate, roasted malt, some burnt notes, and a touch of smoke.  I dont get much from the hops side.  I assume all the bitterness in this brew comes from the roast.  Light to medium body with average carbonation.  While I wouldnt consider it a summer brew, its clean finish and light palate make it a great daily drinker.  Very tasty indeed.

Bottle from Spirits Bayville. Pours out almost a cola color with a startling lack of a pop at first...o no is this undercarbonated? Luckily it isnt. Aroma is of some chocolate, light coffee, roast, and some light earthy/citrusy hops on the finish. Lots of flavor packed into 5%

22oz bottle.  Pours thick and completely opaque with large creamy brown head; could be mistaken for a stout.  Aroma is coffee with some roasty malts.  Flavor is subsequently nutty with a slight sweetness and dry finish.  Slight coffee.

(Bottle) Pours dark brown to black with a light brown head. The aroma is of salt liquorice, coffee, dark bread and some hops in the background. The flavour is light sweet and light to medium bitter with a medium roasted sting. Tones of salt liquorice, coffee, and hops alongside a light toffee-like sting. The mouthfeel is round and fairly smooth with a soft carbonation. Salty and bitter finish. Medium bodied.
Tap.  Aroma is smokey and flavor is smokey and malty.  Body is light.  Received from group drinking a massive amount of samples at Lost Abbey/Port Brewery.

Date: January 1, 2012 Mode: Bottle Source: Everetts Description: Opaque black pour with some head and lacing.  Aroma is coffee, chocolate, and roasted malt.  Taste is similar to aroma with some slight smoke and a dry finish.  Bottle titled Midnight Sessions Lager and bottled 1/7/10.

Quite dark in colour. Aroma has coffee and mocha, a lot of roast malt character. The palate is quite full bodied but clean and the hop bitterness balances it all out. I prefer a schwarzbier with less roast aroma and flavour, but this is a very well made beer and pretty tasty.
Color oscuro claro con espuma ligera poca retención.Aromas torrefactos y malta.Sabor parecido ligero pero con cuerpo.Bien balanceada!

Dark malt, cocoa and a strong earthiness in aroma.  The flavor is coffee, cocoa/chocolate that leads to a dry finish.  Among the best schwarzbiers Ive had, this had the elements of a porter/stout but with a good lager base.  This is one of the best out there as far as schwarzbiers.

Nice black color; Medium slight creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, wood/smoke, chocolate, & coffee; Flavor of roasted malt, caramel, hops, chocolate, and some coffee; Nicely balanced; Overall, very good dark lager.

Shared with Strykzone via Facebook Chat. My bottlle was called Midnight Sessions Lager.  I like good Schwarzbiers and this is a dandy.   Pours inky black  with a handsome tan head and lots of sticky lacing. Nose of roasted malts and burnt toast.  The flavor is very intense and mirrors the aroma with lots of roasted malts. Coffee finish that is very delightful. Great beer.

Bottle. Dark brown with beige head. Some roasty chocolate coffee. A pleasant bitterness. Delicious but Id rather 5 bottles of dark Kruso than 1 bottle of this. What with the economic downturn and that.
From bottle. Pours black with well retained cream head. Chocolatey aroma with a slight metallic edge. Taste is similar, bit of coffee. Nice and rich, more like a porter

22oz bottle in a shaker.  Pours very dark brown with a lacy head.  Aroma of some roasted malts, but also the pale lager style malts and some nice hops.  Flavor the same.  Average texture.  A pretty good beer.

Bomber from Hayduke.  We shared a bottle via facebook chat.  This pours black and it has a gushing dark tan that requires patience while watching it settle.  The nose was roasted notes and chocolate.  Those were prominent in the flavor, especially chocolate.  Fruit managed to pop up but was never big.  The malt was so big.  Bready toast was tasted.  This was a really nice beer.  It is one of those beers that blows away misconstrued ideas of lagers being drab and boring.

Bottle: &nbsp Darkest of browns, moderate to thin light brown head, frothy, dies quickly, spotty lacing. &nbsp 

Very roasty nose, lactose as well and its rather strong. &nbsp Reminds me of a heavily roasted Sweet Stout. &nbsp 

Tastes much the same, malty, somewhat velvety on the tongue, with a lactose twang. &nbsp This to me isnt much of a 

Schwarzbier, but more like a heavily roasted Sweet Stout. &nbsp Slightly dry, even a little chalky. &nbsp Not as 

smokey as I anticipated. &nbsp Fairly smooth while being a bit spritzy. &nbsp Lingering roasted malt sweetness, very 

little campfire. &nbsp Has a lingering lactose like tinge. &nbsp Not bad, smooth, but not as smokey as I was 

expecting.

Bottle. Massive head folhad a stolowed the initial opening. This took a long time to dissipate.When it did it it had a stout like dryness, Its body also had more impact han would expect from a five percentercenter.Perhaps a silly question but is this really a lager?

Ive never had a dark lager before, so I was intrigued to try this one. Slight taste notes of chocolate, and roasty coffee. Not a ton going on all together with this beer, but if you are a fan of darker styles you might find this one good for a hot summer day.

22oz bottle.  This one was so underwhelming.  Poured out nice however, pitch black dark, decent off white head.  Im not sure how this is a swarz, however some decently smoke, but really this is just a black lager that underwhelms.  Smooth and silky, but thats about it, no discerable attributes that really make this one stand out.  Bland.
(Bottle 25/10-2011) Low brown head, almost black color, roasted aroma, fit body, roasted bitter taste.
Black with a big brown head. Aroma is sweet, roasted malt and chocolate. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and roasted moderate bitter finish. Very good schwarzbier. 211011

1 pt 6 fl oz bottle from Kihoskh, København. Pours an entirely black body with a fluffy, light choco colored top. Bready and chocolatey malt aroma. Also fresh smell of plum marmelade and tinned dark fruits. Taste is slightly sweet and well roasted. Chocolate tones and coffee bitterness. Notes of sourish black bread. Mid-bodied with a slick mouthfeel. Finishes fairly dry. Well-crafted with good drinkability.
Big coffee aroma, thin body. Very smooth drinking some vanilla. Slight bitter on the finish.

The pour here is nearly black with just a little amber sneaking through.  On top is a big fluffy head that takes its time settling down to a thin layer.  The aroma shows plenty of chocolate notes along with toasted bread, coffee, and grain.  This is smooth and roasty going down but with a touch of vanilla cream as well that leads to a burnt ashy finish.  I really cant think of a whole lot noteworthy with the flavor thats not mentioned in the aroma.  I must say, this stuff is really damn tasty.  There are nice subtleties to keep the interest and I love the drinkability.  Just kick back and relax with this one.  You dont need massive ingredients or a high abv to be a great beer.

Matt had this one at 3R6P pack for quite a while before I got around to grabbing a bottle but I was pleased to have tried it finally. +++ Sampled from a 22 oz brown bottle this beer poured a black color with a huge foamy brown head that lingered and left some lacing. The aroma was very bitter and roasty with strong notes of coffee and baker chocolate and a bit of vanilla. The flavor was bitter, dryish and very roasty with notes of vanilla, coffee, cola and wood. The finish was long and roasty with lingering wood and coffee. Thick and creamy body. A bit too dry for my taste but quite well made.

Bottle at Brewdog Bar Aberdeen. It pours jet black with a thick, light tan head. The nose is rich coffee, salted liquorice, soy sauce and dark chocolate. The taste is caramel, soy sauce, toffee, salted liquorice, tar, sesame seed and brown sugar, with a dry-roasted malt finish. Medium body and above average carbonation. A tasty Schwarzbier.

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2011 Dark brown pour, think foamy head lingers a while.  High, malty aroma with a hint of cherries.  Sweet aroma.  Good malty flavor with quite a bit of nuttiness.  Pours and looks like a stout, but doesnt coat your tongue the same way, and less bitter.  Very nice.

Pours a deep dark black with a medium sized tan head. Aroma of chocolate, coffee, and roasted malts. Flavor of roasted malts, coffee, and bitterness.  Seems to be overly carbonated, but is still quite good.

Bottled. Dark color, nice medium brown head. Aroma of coffee, roasted malt, bit soapy, some floral and grainy notes. Quite bitter taste, sweet and slight sticky from toffee and caramel, hint of acidic roastedness. Taste lingers on with velvety roasted tones, finishing slightly bitter. Moderate thickness, bit in between creamy and sirupy. Decently balanced. Good beer.

6/8/11. Bomber courtesy scotchzi. Opaque black pour with a nice, creamy tan head. Lots of creamy milk chocolate on the aroma with a touch of tart smokiness in there. Light, sessionable flavor that still delivers coffee, dark chocolate, and a touch of fruitiness. Light mouthfeel with plenty of carbonation. Nice!

Savannah, Ga - Habersham Bevrage Warehouse - 22 oz bomber. Deep dark black pour, thick khaki colored head, light lacing. Aroma has some faint trqces of chocolate, some potting soil earthiness. Flavor has some nice day old black coffee notes, a dollop of bakers unsweetened chocolate and some back end roastiness. Mouthfeel is nice and chalky. Solid  schwarz.
Bottle. Very dark brown with medium beige head. Flavour is roasted malts, chocolate, bitter, coffee, dry, little liquorice, little sweet and hops.
Immediate and pleasant scent of toffee and cappuccino. Black color with foamy tan head. Texture and flavor is like a draught Guiness. Nice smooth roasted malt taste with cocoa and some tobacco.

This brew pours dark brown with a medium tan head that recedes steadily. Stringy lacing on the glass. Aroma of roasted malts and a bit of smoke, plus a bit of hops. Medium body with a roasty malt character backed up by notes of cocoa, hops and a touch of charcoal. The finish is roasty with a hoppy aftertaste. Well done overall.

On tap at Toronado.  Pours dark brown, nearly black, with a small creamy tan head.  Aromas of smoke, cocoa, dark chocolate, and some honey.  The flavor is cocoa and toffee, lightly sweetened with honey, and some bitter coffee.  Very smooth, nearly silky, and easy-drinking.  A very nice brew.  [704]
Bottle pours a deep brown almost black with a huge creamy tan head. Scent is malty. Taste is nutty and lightly roasted malts.

Bottle at home. Pours an opaque black with a tanned head. Sweet with a burned dryness. Aromas of roasted malts and chocolate. Also hints of dried fruits and metals. Medium to high carbonation. Medium to full bodied with a creamy mouthfeel. Dry, toasted finish. Like a mix between a porter and a schwartzbier.

Black pour with a creamy tan head that lingers.  Roasted malt aroma with hints of dark chocolate and nuts.  Lots of roasted malt flavor with dark chocolate and nuts.  Really nice beer! Tastes so much bigger than a lager.
On tap at Lost Abbey.  Pours black with tan head.  Big roasty nose.  Roasty, burnt and finishes dry.  Avg palate.

Bomber bought more than a year ago at Holiday Wine Cellar ($4.29).  Pours a dark cola brown with a half finger of creamy mocha-colored head.  Aroma of smoky dark roasted malts, creamy chocolate, leather, and some nutty coffee.  Flavor has considerable dark chocolate, some smoky and light burnt roasted malts, coffee, and roasted nuts.  Pretty smooth mouthfeel with a lingering lightly bitter-burnt flavor.  (414, 546)
Pours black with chocolate head.  Sweet caramel and roast, chocolate.  Roasty and sweet, chocolaty, caramel.  Slightly astringent.

The one I am drinking is labelled "Midnight Expressions".
The pour is black with a tall, thick dark tan, long lasting head.
Roasty malt aroma, almost smoky.
Richly flavored and smooth, but not heavy in any way.
Very tasty and well done! Ill have another!

Awesome brew. Great color and head on this brew with its nice dark brown/black tint and its nice frofy head. A little bit of smokieness on the mid palate which carries nicely through out the entire taste experince. Nice nutty flvor rides the tastebuds with ease as a perfect balance of carbonation and taste complete the finish. Another epic beer experience from Port Brewing...

Nice schwarzbier.  Hints of smoke across the palate, nice hop bitterness - but doesnt interfere with the great complex malts.  Pours black with lingering tan head.  

On draft at The Belgian Cafe.

The bottle I have says "Midnight Expression" but appears to be the same beer with a new name.  Although it looks opaque at first, its actually has a nice garnet tinge under that thick brown head.  Smoky, roasted aroma coming off followed by a very charred, roasted flavor.  Charcoal, graphite and dark/bittersweet chocolate with a pronounced dryness.   Light bodied as a Schwarzbier should be and the flavor fades off the tongue as quickly as it starts.  Well made and very tasty.

Black appearance with a thin tan head. Aroma is lightly roasted malt, with a hint of chocolate. Flavor is very mild with a hint of toasted malts and chocolate in the finish. Very pleasant dark lager, would make a great session beer.

65cl, as Midnight Sessions Lager, new American brew Anno 2008, from Brouwerij de Molen Bodegraven, complex brew, fruity and roasted, yet easy to drink, balanced, hazy, small head, good brew, yet expensive!
Bottle at the brewery.   Bacony, roasty, malt brew.  Smokey and robust.  Full bodied for a lager.

Bottle from Beermerchants.com.Pours black with a big frothy mocca head. Aroma of roasted malts and chocolate. Taste is roasted, bitter coffee and dark bitter chocolate. Smooth mouthfeel. Lingering dry roasted aftertaste. Very tasteful and delicious beer.

Black pour orange hue light tan head .... aroma of roasted and sweet malts ... taste of mostly roasted malts and sweet malty lager, little smokey and chocolate smooth mouthfeel light bitter acidic finish .... good flavor and sessionable not a bad brew at all

Bomber.  Pitch pour with a rocky light brown head.  Smoky nose with light chocolate roast, some oatmeal, too.  Bitter chocolate taste, smoke and near-astringent roast.  Bitter cocoa aftertaste heading, again, toward astringency.  Medium-full body.  Good, hard to think of this as a lager.

bomber.  Pours black with fluffy brown head, which lasts quite awhile with nice lacing.  Dark, malty aroma heavy on roast, with actually a subtle smoked pork aspect, and light tones of cocoa.  Flavor is not as bitter as expected, no dark chocolate / coffee tones, but more roasted stew, wow, they could have classified this as a smoke beer and had me fooled.  It is interesting that the malts theyve used have produced this without smoked malt.  Dont get me wrong, its not incredibly smoky / ashy, and what Im describing isnt too pronounced, but there is kind of the roasted meat / corn / stew aspect that alot of smoke beers have.  As there warms there is indeed more of a bitterness, however subtle, on the finish.  Overall a nice schwarzbier, its medium bodied, smooth, and easy drinking.  Still, its not terribly complex or anything, but worth a buy for one try.
Poured black with a small light-brown head. Toasted malts, coffee, and a good amount of hops on the nose. Sweet and malty with some noticeable bitterness. Good beer all around.

Beermerchants.com. Rich and roasted, black as pitch. Bitter, smokey, fairly dry, with some fruit in the flavour. For me, this is a stout by any other name, maybe a touch lighter bodied. An interesting mix of styles, maybe not quite as refreshing as the label makes out.

Black, and completely opaque. Rich, thick tan head. Smells like coffee, with some grassy notes. Flavor is coffee and some other roasty notes, plus some red wine and ashy  flavors. Some odd basement flavors, too. Tasty brew.

Pours black with tan, foamy head. The head had a fairly rigid structure. Lightly burnt/roasted aroma, some molasses. Light and modestly lively on the tongue. A tiny amount of spice and a lot of molasses initially, but the finish just exploded with that roasted malt flavor and trailed into a lingering grass/bitter feel. Loved the huge finish.
Roasted malt/coffee initially. Finishes on the light side. I like this beer. It has excellent drinkability, This beer would complement food well.

I had this today and was labeled Midnight Expressions. Very smoky malt character with a taste that is strongly reminiscent of a dry Irish stout. At 4%ABV this is good session beer for dark lager-lovers. I personally like heavier dark lagers but I wont hold it against such a delicious beer.

Pitch black, a touch clear dark brown at the bottom near bright light with a dense, thick light brown head - very very nice! Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, toffee and a big bit of vanilla. Medium to Light-bodied; Deep roasty flavour with a little smokey character, a touch of coffee and a minor dose of hops near the end. Aftertaste is mostly roasty with a very good flavour profile and a complexity that is pretty good for the style - a lot of porter type tastes dominate this one, even though its not an ale! Overall, a very nice beer - definitely worth drinking if you can find it! I sampled this 65 cL bottle purchased at Olive Tree Market Place in San Diego, California on 08-February-2011 for US$4.49 sampled at home on the other coast in Washington on 28-February-2011.
Bomber bottle labelled Midnight Expressions. Pours black with tan head. Roast aroma, roast taste, nice mouth feel. Much more of a beer than the number would suggest, but still sessionable.
Bottle. Actually says Midnight Expressions! Dark beer with creamy brown head and lacing. Big tasty black flavour. Like a sweet stout mixed with bitter black chocolate.

Aroma is rich and smoky with undertones of malt, molasses, yeast and coffee - very like a good stout or porter. It pours a near-opaque sable with a thick, fluffy, fairly persistent light tan head. Flavor is mainly malty with an undertone of roast coffee and hints of molasses. Texture is fizzy as cola, dancing on the tongue and all the way down.

A very interesting beer.  Pours pitch freaking black with a mocha head that dissipates most of the way and leaves little lacing.  Aroma, I swear to god... soy sauce.  I had one other person confirm this.  The head gives off a strange, soy saucey aroma.  But that goes away as the head dissipates.  The rest of the nose is sweet, almost chocolaty malt.  Taste is very malty, with dark flavors found in stouts and porters.  But then the beer cleans out, and ends slightly bitter and dry as a lager should.  Cool beer.  I like it.

Roasted malts bordering on burnt; not a lot of discernible hop flavor or aroma, but also not the complex malt qualities I hoped for or expected.  I would like to try this beer again when I can be more certain of the freshness.
Pours black with brown head. Decent lacing. Smells of toasted malts, caramel, chocolate, and coffee. Tastes are on par with smells. Extremely carbonated with a dry finish.

22oz bottle labeled as "Midnight Expression".  Bottled Dec 17, 2010. Pours dark brown to black with a large brown head that leaves a foamy ring and some clumps of lacing while holding a small cap.  Aroma features a surprising amount of coffee and coffee beans, tons of heavily roasted if not burnt malts, dark bread/rye.  Great to excellent strength.  Flavor doesnt quite stand up to the aroma but it still quite good and features more dark roasted/burnt malts, coffee, some chocolate, bread, a bit of pine and citrus hops underneath.  Lightly sweet with some bitterness.  Mouthfeel is thin, high carbonation.  Damned good Schwarzbier, even a bit better than the excellent Duck Rabbit version mostly thanks to the excellent aroma.
22oz bottle.  New to GA.  Black color, tan head.   Toasted grain scent.  Flavor of burnt cereal.  Sweet coffee, some wood,  and charcoal.  Not for everyones palate.  A bit too carbonated for me.
Highly carbonated. Head exploded and took five minutes to settle. When it did I was left with a smooth dark beer with a toasted malt presence as well as smoky coffee. Pleasant but uninspiring.

bottle labeled "midnight expression lager".  black with a large, fluffy beige head.  salty nuts and roast aroma.  very light body.  dry finish.  chalky and roasty flavor with dark chocolate.  lager crispness.
bottle at home ... sweet roast light burnt roast malt nose ... burnt front ... toffee malts ...  deep roast ... dark malts ... little odd ... but quite nice... definite light charcoal roast.

Bottle; Pour is a dark brown with a fizzy, frothy tan head that retains well. Slight roasty nutty aroma. Light bodied, watery mouth feel. Light cocoa note, nuttiness, roasted coffee - the finish is smooth. It feels pretty boring, honestly. But - I enjoyed it overall for the style.

This has a slightly roasty aroma. Dark black but little head. This has a decent amount of coffee flavor but quite too much, so its drinkable. A good thickness, but it doesnt last too long. A bit filling but good.

22oz bottle from Secret Santa 2010 
Appearance: Pours very dark brown, almost black, with a medium sized beige head and some lacing 
Aroma: Toasted malts, dark chocolate and some smokiness 
Taste: Lively mouthfeel. Dark malts, ashy, chocolate and some bitterness in the finish 
A nice beer, a winter warmer to sip on next to a roaring fire. Enjoyed this one.

Poured into a flute.

3.5 A: Very much overcarbonated, but didnt explode out of the bottle. First pour gave me 1/8 glass beer and 7/8 head. Anyway, black color. Several fingers of frothy soda-like light brown head that retains well, but doesnt lace well at all.

3.5 S: Roasted barley up front. Light dark fruitiness, but this is very soft. There really isnt much going on here.

3.0 T: Again there isnt a whole lot going on. Light roastiness and a subtle fruitiness. Not bad, but there are plenty of other Schwarzies out there that offer more.

3.5 M: Light body. Overcarbonated. Very smooth though.

3.5 D: Like I said before, this is okay, but not my schwartzbier of choice.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-29-2010 20:38:04
Tap at the brewery.  Very dark maroon color.  Aroma of chocolate biscuits.  Taste is chocolate with a bitter background.  Nice stuff.
It is so difficult to find great lagers in the USA. This is a GREAT, Big and Bold, and smokey and licorice tasting lager.

31-DEC-2010, bottle from "Fish & Beer".
Black(!).
Pours very thick black fluid.
Very roasted. Very full schwarzbier...
...pure chocolate taste...
...lovely!
Sweeter than most schwarzbiers, but hey it is a very fine brew. Just to expensive for a rebuy.

From a 220z bottle bought at the Craft Beer Outlet in NE Philly.  Bottling date is 1/7/10... thats almost a year after I bought it.  Negative points for CBO for keeping it on the shelf that long.  Pours a Midnight black with a ton of extra head.  After the head subsides, the aroma is of coffee, a tiny bit of licorice and a bit of smoke.  Mouthfeel is clean and crisp with a good amount of carbonation.  Taste is of coffee and cocoa.  Dry and a tiny bit mediciney.   Overall a very good schwartzbeer.  I dont agree that its the best, that right is reserved for Sprechter, but it is damn good.

From bottle courtesy of dpjuart. Chocolate, coffee, roasted barley, and mild hops. Schwarzbier profile in aroma. Dark brown-black with thin off-white lacing head. Medium body with medium-light carbonation. Starts medium dry with good roasted character, like a stout and schwarzbier mix. Mild smoky finish and nutty bitter after with chocolate notes.

Pours dark black with very little head. Dark and roasty malt with a little coffee. Flavor is a bit light for the look and smell, but a nice smooth roasted flavor. Slightly sweet, but overall pretty nice.
Bottle from Ølbutikken. Huge head with excellent duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are rich roast malt, nuts, caramel and hops.

First of all, by the name and style of lager, I originally thought it would be like Full Sail Session...when I poured into my snifter and saw a dark brew, I was delighted.

A: poured into a snifter. the beer pours an impenetrable black/dark mahogany. No head at all on top, besides a haze of tan swirls. Lack of a head is the reason for the low score.

S: almost smells like a stout. Rich roasted dark malts are the lead, which I pulled coffee, toffee, some figs and raisins as well. A mild hint of chocolate, but very faint.

T: Wow...I now have a total understanding as to why Tomme is the fucking man. This is by far the most amazing schwarzbier I have ever tasted, and probably ever will. Deep and intense roasted dark malts, almost make this taste like a stout or a porter. Chocolate and coffee tones are the major flavors. This is a very sweet/malty version of this style. Some light hints of dark fruits like fig and cherry.

M: carbonation was a little light, but it enhanced the malts in my opinion. The most full bodied schwarzbier ever!

D: at 5% and the amazing flavor, this beer is a great "session" brew. extremely drinkable.

bottle thanks to secret santa poured a super dark brown in color bordering on black with a nice fluffy mocha colored head. aroma is nice and roasted, hazelnuts, chocolate, coffee, and some creamy sweetness. mouth feel is light with plenty of carbonation. flavor has roasted malts, lightly bitter chocolate, there are some light hops kicking, and a light sweetness in the finish. well done clean beer that is nice and flavorful for the abv.

Bomber pours dark black with large frothy dark tan head. Aroma is roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, and molasses. Taste is similar to aroma very dry, nice balance of bitterness and sweetness. Taste is slightly watery but doesnt diminish from the taste and makes this very sessionable for a dark beer. Well done!
Bottle @ Hj Hansen, Odense. Pours black with a small creamy brown head. Roasted nose and flavor. A bit of coffee, chocolate, grain and hops. Very smooth and oily. Low carbonation. Very tasty.

Bottled. Aroma has light roast, caramel, some coffee. Clear, black coloured beer with a slight off-white, medium head. The taste is light bitter, a bit sweet, bit roasted and has caramel and some coffee, some grassy hops as well. Light bodied beer. Nice.

Pour is black with medium tan head.  Aroma of roasted malts, coffee, some chocolate.  Taste is roasted malt all the way through with a slight dry, bitter finish with the hops.  Thin bodied with above average carbonation.  Very drinkable

Bottle shared at Euston Tap. Pours pitch black with a sturdy, beige head. Big and roasted malt aroma with some sugary notes. Flavor is rich, sweet and very malty, with further roast, brown sugar, caramel and faint vanilla. Medium in body with average to lively carbonation. Finish is lightly dry and acidic, with more sweet, roasted malts and faint, coffee-like bitterness. Very good beer.

Bottle. Creamy lightbrown excellent mostly lasting head. Black colour. Heavy malty and light hoppy aroma. Heavy bitter flavor. Roasted and nice chocolate notes. Moderate bitter long finish. Creamy palate. Excellent scwhartzbier.

Bottle. Very dark walnut brown, light brown head that laces early then forms a ring. Coffee and dark chocolate aroma. Bitter roast, coffee, bakers chocolate flavours. Finish is dry and slightly vegetal with medium bitterness. Solid.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Bottle. Pours a dark brown/black color with a small off-white head. Has a roasted malty grainy chocolate and caramel aroma. Roasted malty chocolate flavor with some hints of caramel. Has a roasted malty chocolate finish with some bitterness in the aftertaste.

Bomber from August trip to Colorado.  Pours a light-consuming black with a moderate, short-lived pale brown head.  Aroma is as roasty (read burnt) a roast coffee can be, as strong as any RIS competitor.  Flavor brings a robust push of roast coffee, dark chocolate, and liquid smoke.  The balance brought in by the earthy and fruity hops is surprisingly good, and this brew has a wacky depth of flavor for a schwarzbier.  9 out of 10 commoners would confuse this for a good stout, if not for the slightly thinner body.  Awesome brew!

~Smooth roasty coffee and chocolate aroma.
~Pours black with redish amber tints, Small lasting brown head.
~Bitter roasty chocolate coffee like flavor some light earthy hop notes.
~Med light body, med CO2, dry roasty finish that lingers.
~Pretty delicious swarzbier. Clean roasty flavor, refreshing.
UPDATED: OCT 3, 2014 near black in appearance.  smooth and very drinkable.  lots of roasty malts and just enough hops to notice.  nice lager.  its a toss up between this and hot rocks.
Bottle at WBF-Raleigh on 04/24/2010. Dark black body with a medium frothy tan head. Sweet roast, chocolate and light molasses flavor with a good bitter finish. Medium body with moderate carbonation.

Bottle shared by a friend. Black pour with a medium tan head. Chocolate nose with roasty coffee. Ill be honest, theres nothing about this aroma that tells me its a lager. Sure its slightly thinner smelling than your typical very well made stout, but it still smells like a stout. Flavor is chocolate, with a bit of sweetness and a roasty coffee finish.

UPDATED: JUN 29, 2013 650 ml bottle @ Olutravintola Pannuhuone. Rated @ 30.7.2010.
Pours a black colour with a off-brown head. Roasted coffee and malts on the nose with dark chocolate. The taste is very dry; coffee, malts and chocolate just like in the aroma. Very stoutish. Medium bodied, oily and a bit watery mouthfeel with soft carbonation. Good and light. 7-4-7-3-15 3.6
650 ml bottle.
Pours a black colour with a foamy beige head. Aroma of roasted malts, almonds, birch leaves and strong burnt biscuit. Flavour of roasted malts, burnt biscuit, grassy hops, wood, salty licorice and weak fruitiness. Light bodied, disturbingly high carbonation and a lingering, roasty, bitter finish. Harsh and too much carbonation, but nice hop profile. 7-3-7-3-14 3.4

Bottle @ Delirium Cafe, Brussels. Pours a dense, near-black body with a small off-white head. Aroma is roasted barley with the "wrong" kinda hops (theres one of the American styles I really cant take, but I dont know its name yet). Taste is very similar, with few surprises: roasty tones with some malty sweetness. Pretty straightforward, and with a slightly watery palate compared to the big roast notes. Not really my thing, but OK for a schwarz I suppose.

22oz bottle. Pours a very dense brown, mostly black colored body with an inch thick, dense and creamy, brown head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is sweet roasts with dusty, milky and dark chocolates. Some molasses, coffee, toasted bread, deep caramel, and a hint of smoke. A bit of a lactose acidity. Flavor is more the same. Slightly salted, sweet roasts and dark chocolate up front with a bit of a milky sweetness. A light coffee presents itself in the middle along with some molasses, deep caramel, toasted bread, and a bit of a roasty acidity from the grains. Cocoa and roast grow into the finish where this has a pretty firm bitterness with some sweet earth and a hint of smoke. Dry with a lengthy aftertaste following a medium-light body and moderate, soft carbonation. Very easy drinking. Overall, a fine example of the style. Well balanced with a pleasant roast and bitterness level with just the right amount of acidity and sweetness. The Schwarzbier style is quickly becoming one of my favorites and this beer is one of the reasons. Excellent.

Bottle; bought from Beermerchants, consumed at home. Bomber. Poor lacing, incredibly dark colour; intense IBUs, dark guey chocolate, burnt toast, bitter coffee grains, leather, wood, good balance, low carbanation, creamy and oily. A great dark lager.

Black with a medium sized beige head. Aroma had fairly hard roasted malt, liquerice, coffee and dark chocolate. Flavor had hard roasted malt, dark chocolate, liquerice and dark chocolate. Finished sweet and roasted.

(Bottled, 0.65l, sampled 2010-06-18) Hazy, very dark brown color with a smallish, firm, beige head. Aroma of milky sourness, roasted malt and coffee, as well as a touch of licorice. Strongly roasted flavor is nicely balanced by full maltiness, licorice, and black coffee. Hops well balanced and not intrusive. Medium body, slightly slicky and smooth-carbonated. A pleasantly full-bodied and balancedly roasty brew for the price and ABV.

A damn fine beer, I would drink it until my liver gave way. Nothing offensive at all, just beer bliss. Would get again fo sho.
I didnt think i was going ot like it but i did. Very tasty, full flavored, heavy roast, good clean flavors, nice astringency.

It is always good to see craft breweries trying their hands at lagers. Well, I should qualify that. It is always good to see a craft brewery who actually has the skill to do it properly try their hand at making a lager and that is just what Port did on this one. The appearance is the only real negative on this one. Its a nice enough garnet black color but the head is sort of foamy and dull gray in color. It doesnt look awful but it also doesnt strike me as particularly great. But, oh, the nose is wonderful! A thick, rich porter or even stout-like roast character dominates. Generally a schwartzbier will have a somewhat porter-like character but this is really up there w/ some greats like Founders porter as far as the rich, roasty aroma. The flavor is not on quite the same level. It might just be a hair thin, which is really only disappointing compared to the nose. The coffee and chocolate richness keeps up reasonable well and any sweetness is well matched w/ a smooth bitterness in the finish. I actually dont know if Id really call this strictly an authentic take on the schwarzbier style as its done in its homeland but an American take and perhaps somewhat better or at least more interesting because of it.

A black bodied brew with a lively tan head. The aroma immediately comes through with notes of caramel, milk chocolate, toffee, and roasted malts. The flavor is powerful roasted malts that border on charred in their nature. Espresso grounds, bakers chocolate, cocoa nib, and mild lactic sugar come through as well. The palate is creamy, smooth, and surprisingly viscous. The finish is dry in a roasty, chalky sort of way. A damn good Schwartzbier
22 oz bomber.   Dark brown opaque pour with a medium tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt.  Dry taste of roasted almonds and malt with a nice medium body.  Lasting dry finish.

The head stays for a long while compared to other brews and is a great characteristic. Its got a really complex flavor of malt, coffee, nuts, and finishes with a dark chocolate aftertaste. Its simply amazing. The mild carbonation allows that flavors to really shine and allows your palate to notice all the subtle hints that the brew has.

Pour is super dark umber approaching black. Large, tan, foamy head with good retention and lacing.

Lots of roasty toasty malts on the nose. Bakers chocolate, raisin, toasted nuts, a hint of bacon fat even. 

Taste is bitter malt, lots of coffee-bean, caramel, toasted pecans, long bitter finish with some layering as well.

Palate is medium to full, high carb but obviously low alcohol. Carb perhaps a tad high but not horribly so. 

Overall a good session beer although i would have liked it even better if they had shaved another point off the ABV. Still, lots of flavor for the low Alcohol investment and definitely worth a taste.

From Ølbutikken, Copenhagen, DK.
Bottled, 190610.
Black with off-white head. Aroma of roasted malt and coffee, Flavor of malt, coffee and spices,

660 ml bottle. Finland.
Black colour with small tan head.
Roasted malt, liquorice, bitter hops and some coffee in stout/porter like aroma. Roasted malt, coffee, liquorice, some chocolate and bitter hops in flavour. Quite heavy for a Schwarzbier.

Aroma precedes a far lesser taste.  So a port brewing dark lager.  2nd or 3rd favorite brewer wants to take crack at this less than beer style.  Is this a great schwartzbier? maybe.  A great beer? no.  This is the last beer I have before 400 but I still have much to learn.  Can you coax greater flavors out of the lager yeast?  I hope so.  This is one of the cheaper Port beers (outside of the brewery gift shop) that you can get, and possibly in contention for the best per style....BUT, meh.   Overall, meh (thanks Simpons & M-W for making meh a word). Meh, Meh, Meh.

Pours black with a small beige head; aroma of roasted malt and roasted cocoa beans with hints of licorice; medium body, moderate carbonation; flavor is roasted malty, chocolaty, light bitter with hints of licorice in the finish.

Bottled. Rubyish amber brown colour, mediumsized off-white head that leaves some lace. Aroma is coffee, chocolate,some roasted malts and caramel malts along with mild burnt and ashy notes as well. Flavour is coffee, chocolate, ashes, some roasted malts, mild burnt wooden notes as well as some caramel. Very plesant Schwarzbier.

22 oz.

A: Pours a very dark brown with dark amber on the bottom when put up to the light, along with a one finger tan head.
S: Chocolate and coffee aromas.
T: Bittersweet dark chocolate with hop bitterness in the finish.
M: Light body but head and heavy carbonation stay with this the whole way through.

(Bottle at Pikkulintu) Poured black. Head was medium sized and light brown. Aroma contained malts, roastedness and chocolate. Palate was full bodied and dry with medium carbonation. Flavours were burntness, roastedness, coffee, chocolate, mildly sweetness and medium bitterness. Aftertaste was burnt and bitter.

Bottled @Beer Hunters 0.66 ltr
Deep ruby brown color, small beige head. Intensive coffee, cocoa powder, chocolate and caramel in the nose. Quite good body for 5% beer. Coffee, caramel, slightly ashy dark malts. Some bitter notes in the finish - not sure if it is from hops of is it bitterness of coffee. Coffeish, decent Schwarzbier.

A Mes rate. Bottle thanks to Owen.An opaque black / brown colour with a good beige head and great retention. Really interesting aroma. Rich earthy malt and some glorious chocolate bitterness along with just a lick of amonia, but in a pleasant way. Similar flavour that is slightly floral and just a little soapy. The chocolate comes through beautifully in the finish though. Its such a challenging beer on the senses. I know its a lager but all this black stuff comes at me at the same time. Its the best thing about drinking a schwartzbier. Not my favourite of styles but just really really interesting.

Bomber. Aroma is roasted malt, cocoa and espresso. Very similar to a Stout. Appearance is black with a half inch of light brown head. Taste starts off with intense dark roast malt and bitter chocolate flavors followed by medium roast coffee, roast nuts, toasted cereals and a hint of vanilla. Lots of intermingling malt flavors and bitter roastiness. No caramel malt sweetness here. Mouthfeel is dry with medium carbonation. Finish is heavy on the coffee with some more bitterness and a lingering smoky aftertaste. Overall flavor reminds me a of a dry, bitter Coffee Stout. The relatively low ABV adds to its drinkability.

Deep black pour with a thick creamy tan head.  Very sticky and inviting.  The nose is quite creamy and chocolatey with a touch of soft malted milk character as well.  Chewy sweetness along with a touch of almost smoky cocoaish flavour.  Soft and earthy with a touch of light lingering cocoa.  Clean and quite fresh tasting this is a damn fine schwarzbier.
Black with a small tan head. Aroma of peanut butter and malt. Smells like a peanut butter sandwich. Flavor is very rich and mildly bitter very smooth mouthfeel. Delicious.

Black liquid with a creamy, foamy light brown to mocha head. Good schwarzbier aroma. Lots of roasted German malt. A little bit of citrus is in the mix.  The malt is chocolate and biscuity with some good rosasted notes in the end. The hops are kind of citric and floral, but theyre way in the background, hiding behind the chocolate roast. Smooth and creamy. Just a little thin in the finish. A bit of bitter astringency in the aftertaste.

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2010 Had on tap at St. Stevens with Katie. Pour was. Thick dark brown almost black with medium lacing off white head. Aroma is roasted Manta, coffee like. Flavor is a rush of chocolate and molasis. Coffee follows.through into the aftertaste

My bottle of of Midnight Sessions had a moderate, tan head. Very dark color and opaque. Tiny bubbles throughout. I got mostly coffee smells, but not a very strong aroma. I found this beer to be surprisingly sharp in the taste. A couple touches too bitter for my tastebuds, for a dark lager. Maybe the balance was off for my bottle? The carbonation was decent leading to an okay mouthfeel. I thought this lager was a little thin and watery. Not good, not bad. This was fine, but I wouldnt recommend it to anyone.

Served on draft at Monks.

Pours a deep dark mahogany amber/chestnut brown color that is completely opaque with only the slightest of dark c
golden mahogany edges when held to a light source. Frothy two finger dark tan head with excellent retention, only slowly fading into a lasting ring that leaves chunks of soapy lacing behind.

Deep dark roasted malt aroma with hints of bitter dark chocolate, smoke, charcoal, toffee, nut and subtle hops. I know this is a schwarzbier but I was shocked how smokey and authentic this smells. Of course there is a slight American twist with the slight citrus and earthy hops but this beer is roasted and smokey with hints of burnt toast and BBQ.

Chewy full body with a nice lactic creamy feel along with a beautiful smoked malt character that isnt overpowering at all. Deep roasted flavor with hints of nut, toffee, chocolate, caramel and burnt toast. Slightly bitter hops provide the perfect compliment to the smokey roasted notes. There is also a subtle dark fruit presence, especially dark cherry thatnprovides a nice sweetnessto the deep roasted notes. This beer is perfectly balanced and extremely quaffable. This is a nice introduction to smoked lagers. No too overpowering with a lot of comlexity balancing it out but ruach/smoked beers fans will love this beer. Highly recommended!

Location: 22 oz bottle from NickD717, 5/17/10


Aroma: The nose is chocolate malts, caramel, some roasted malts, and vanilla

Appearance: Pours a dark brown color with a lasting, fizzy, light brown head

Flavor: The taste is taste is heavily malty with lots of strong roasted components, chocolate, coffee, and vanilla, some bitterness in the finish goes along with the lingering roasted malt flavors

Palate: This one has a slightly acidic feel, the carbonation is lively, and a long finish

Overall Impression: 
This beer works pretty well.  It has a lot of flavor to it, lots of roasted and malty goodness.  A nice beer.  Thanks, Nick!

Bottle, bought @ Ølbutikken.
enjoyed at the final match day of the Primera Division: Barcelona -  Valladolid
Very dark chestnut with a small, fizzy, cola-like head. Aroma has lovely notes of coffee, roasted malts, dark chocolate. Quite crisp. Medium carbonation, lovely dry and lightish mouthfeel. Flavour is elegantly balanced, very dry. Lots of coffee, hard roasted malts, muscovado sugar, dark chocolate. Long lasting, dry and fairly bitter aftertaste with some flowery hoppiness. Very nice.

Bottle. Pitch black body with some mahogany edges and a brownish beige head. Aromas of coffee, roast, burnt popcorn and straw. Taste is mildly sweet with medium bitterness. Flavors of chocolate, smoke, roasted malt, anise, light honey. Palate is creamy and medium. Finish is smoky/ashy bitterness.

22 oz. bottle via trade with daknole- thanks again, Dak!  Pours a dark, hazy brown with a small tan head that leaves a ring around the inner edge of the glass.  Aroma of roasted malts, dust, chocolate, toasted nuts, and lagery hops.  Flavor of roased chocolate malts, toast, caramel, rust, cardboard, and wet tobacco leaves.  Medium-bodied, with mild carbonation and a vegetal mouthfeel.  Really easy to drink, and absolutely sessionable.  Very nice schwarzbier.

A german style Schwartz beer brewed in the states and bought in Denmark at Ølbutikken, Copenhagen. The pour is thicker than a regular scwarz beer - but this is certainly not a regular brewery anyway. The pour is almost black with a fine latte-brown head that fades slowly.  The aroma is burn malts and close to warm old fashioned scandinavian rye bread, Licorice, smoke and a bit of dark sirup. Clearest of all are the roasty and burned notes though (and that is some how in my world quite opposit thatn expected from the comercial description...summer? The palate is of cause due to the style rather light and watery but anyway there is a fine oilyness that smoothens it. Burned rubber, tar and leather is the impression from the dark bitterness. The taste is long lasting and leaves a great impression and fine finish full of hops and caramel sweetness. For a schwartz beer this is pretty darn good.

Bottled. Dark brown coloured. Light  brown head. Aroma of chocolate, light roast, light liqourice, light coffee and some sweetness. Flavour of sweetness, roast, spice and chocolate. Medium to full bodied. Has a sweet and roasty and cohocolaty bitterness in the end. Quite nice.

On tap @ Craft Ale House Limerick PA - didnt take notes while I was there, but from memory a delicious robust almost porter like (but not as much body or the sweetness of ale yeast) flavor.  I could drink a bunch of this and be very happy.
From the tap poured dark brown with a fair amount of head.  Toasted malty flavor with a quick finish.

Beer was from a bottle.  Poors black with a nice tan head.  Aroma is predominately of roasted malt.  Flavor is excellent.  Reminiscent of a stout except very clean.  Slight bitterness comes through from what appears to be roasted malt only, but Hops are definately there.  Slight sweetness helps balance the whole package.  Palate is great, with a smooth lager finish.  Makes you want to have another sip after each drink.  Overall this beer is excellent.  I look forward to having it again

5 ounce sample on tap at the Davis Graduate.  Its pretty rad that they have this beer AND firestone walker velvet merkin on at the same time.  Oh yea, they also have Uberhoppy on tap, too.  Anyway, this beer has a nice roasted choco-coffee-anise aroma with some slight metallic lager hints present.  Mostly opaque dark mahogany body with virtually no head present.  Imagine that?  Very bitter chalky roasted burnt flavor to start with some black patent malts in there as well.  Metallic and spicy hop flavors are present in the finish.  Very stout-like, despite being a lager.  Nice.

Pours a pitch black with a tan head which fades to spotty lacing.  Aroma is of roasted malt, epresso, and chocolate, and some smoke.  flavor is of dark roasted malts, epresso beans, coco, wine/port, and some burnt bread. Has a medium body with a good carbonation level and and a clean, bitter roasted finnish.  overall, a very tasty and drinkable beer.
Pours cloudy black. Taste like a smooth, thin porter with hints of bitter cocoa.

Bottle listed as Midnight Sessions - SJ BevMo

Aroma - lightly smoked, huge dark roasted malt/espresso bean nose with a not-so-subtle chocolate appearance.  

Appearance - jet black body, cream 1" tan head with some lasting power.  Spotty lacing left behind in clumps.  

Taste - roasted coffee, chocolate in a melding of a nice mocha drink.  Some wine-like components witht the sweetness...kinda port-like yet very easy to drink.
 
Palate - medium bodied, a little heavy with the carbonation but nothing overhanded.  Finish is clean, with a easy bitterness.

Overall - very nice, easy to approach and a nice example to introduce someone to this style.

Bomber thanks to footbalm. Pours a cloudy brown color with a medium beige head. The aroma is sweet malts, nutty. The flavor is smooth and rich; heavily toasted malts, light nutty flavor, rich undertones of chocolate and rich malts. Very drinkable and flavorful. Nice!

22 oz. bottle. Pours a thick, mocha head, of long duration, over a clear, dark brown (SRM 30) body.....nose is light chocolate/cocoa, bit of coffee, light hop spice.....taste is dry, with light chocolate and light coffee, finishing lightly bitter....mouth feel is medium to light, carbonation adds a creamy sensation. This meets the description of a Schwartzbier almost perfectly. Aromas, flavors and appearance are right on, and although this is not a favorite style of mine, they have really done a good job with it. BJCP 8/3/15/4/8

22oz. bomber served in a SA Perfect Pint glass. Poured a deep brown/black with a finger of tan head. Bottle conditioned. Chocolate malt with some noble hops in the aroma. Medium bodied. Lots of chocolate malt in the flavor. Porterish flavor profile. Roasty and malty with a long lingering chocolate malt finish. Different take on a schwarzbier.

The Dan Journal #336.  Tasted 4/1/10.  22oz bomber.  Rather opaque with a dark brown hue.  Spiraling head with a khaki ring of head.  Aromas of cocoa, chocolate and coffee.  Great roasted malty nose.  Medium bodied with a totally dominant malt character.  Huge effervescence.  This has a lot of palate for the style.  Toasty malts immediately backed up by the citrus astringent effervescence.  The finish is both sweet and bitter.  Great nutty, graham cracker malt flavor.  So smooth, so nice!
On draft at Stone. Pours a midnight black with tiny white head. Aroma and taste was roasted coffee, smokey. Very smooth and enjoyable. Frothy pallet. Overall very session-able.
From a 22oz bottle,Black,brownish head,light body,smoke,great beer ,might buy more.

Wait this is a lager? Pours deep deep brown/black with tan head, aroma is nice smoky and coffee flavors.  Taste is coffee up front leading into smoky notes that finishes a bit bitter and dry.  Hear its from serpent stouts second runnings, would love to try the regular version.  Great lager!

Draft at Teresas. Pours dark brown hazy with a creamy beige head. Aroma of roast, malts, barley, figs, and pepper. Light bodied with a thin, watery body. Tastes like a stout without the body to support the heavy flavors. Okay.

Draft at teresas with pat. Pours a pitch black. Aroma is very light with nice notes of roast and maybe chocolate. Mouthfeel is really thin and smooth - a blind tasting would suggest a really delicious pale, roasted lager.

pours a black with a small khaki head, and some lacing.

smell is of roasted malt, some coffee, a little smoke, and cocoa.

taste is bold, roasted malt, cocoa, some coffee, and hops in back, ends a little bitter.

tasting on 3/6/10.  pours a dark brown with a tan head... slight smoke nose with some roasted malts... light to medium body with low carbonation and smooth smoke, chocolate, roast, and slight coffee notes.

Pours a black color with a dark tan head.Got the aroma of roasted malts and coffee.The flavor is of roasted malts,coffee and rye bread.The body is medium and the finnish is real smooth.Overall a fine brew.
Sampled in a 22oz. Pours dark brown / black. Aroma is nicely smoked. Flavor is smoked but not over done. Really a nice brew.

Bomber. Black with medium tan head that fades. Aroma of lightly roasted malt, light chocolate, bread, earth/dirt. Taste is mostly roasted and had light hop bit at end. Crisp and thin-medium bodied with lots of carbonation.

UPDATED: MAR 5, 2012 Draft at Jerrys. Black with good, creamy cappuccino head / Roast barley and chocolate nose / Medium body, lively carbonation, with long, toasty finish / Flavors of roast coffee, bittersweet chocolate, coconut and oak / An outstanding flavor profile for a lager.

Decent black lager action. Super velvety smooth on the mouthfeel which was really enjoyable. Dark as night in that oh so good way. Mild roast, mild sweetness, mild milk chocolate. For what it was, it was dank!

Pours clear dark brown, inky in the glass, cherry brown around the edges, with a two-finger tan head, very good and lasting lacing.  Aromas of dark chocolate, coffee, toasted rye bread, and grass.  Medium-thin body, lively, crisp, lightly dry.  Lightly sweet flavor, a touch savory, more coffee, rye bread, and some citrus.  Well balanced and very drinkable.

Port Brewing
Midnight Sessions Dark Lager
Not a huge lager fan, but thought we would give it a try. Pours very dark with a slight reddish tinge at the edge of the glass. Medium tan head with decent retention. Aroma of malt and black tea with a hint of coffee. Taste is of a subdued stout with hints of coffee and dark malt. Very smooth, but not sweet enough for my taste. I could drink a lot of it, but I could drink a lot of Bass too. Somewhat dry finish. Not bad, but not my style.
couldnt believe i was drinking a lager. dark very dark with a thin mocha colored head. Aroma of Chocolate, nuts, a bit of coffee, and the roasted malt. Clean crisp and refreshing as most lagers

On draught at Hamiltons Tavern (San Diego, CA): This is my first beer on my first night as a new resident of California (moved from West Palm Beach, FL). And oh, what a good one to start off my west coast beer journey with, considering Ive never rated a Schwarzbier. Pours dark brown with a thick tan head. Aroma of bittersweet burnt chocolate, some coffee, smoke, and citrus. Smooth and soft mouthfeel. Noticable hops in the flavor along with roasted malts, licorice, wood, and faint coffee. A little thin. Drinkability: Bittersweet, with a clean, soft roastiness. Pairing: Spicy barbeque; hearty roast meat. Rebuy: Yes. #279 on 19022010, DG.

A: Black, as one would expect from the name, with a thin mocha colored head.

S: Chocolate, nuts, a bit of coffee, and the roasted malt.

T: Very roasted/toasted flavor, a bit of coffee bitterness, and a mild sweetness at some points.

M: Kind of light in body, but a lot more punch than a typical lager.

D: Good drinkability, as you would expect from a lager.
Pours dark brown. Woodsy, herbal bitterness. Too fizzy for my taste, but interesting.

22 oz bottle that Im plesantly suprised about.  Nose is super sweet and malty.  Dark fruit, red fruit, sweet malt.  Maybe some clove or something.  Lovely.  Pour looks like strong porter: Black with strong anf long tan head.  Just not as sticky as a good porter or stout.  Taste has sweet fruit, sharp malt, lager bite.  Looks much heavier than it is.  I wouldnt have believed it from the initial pour, but this 22 is going down damn quickly and easily.  Nice beer!
Bottle. Pours dark black with a creamy tan head. Flavor is chocolate and iced coffee, and some hop character.
Dark pour with a tan head.  One finger head dissipated quickly.  Sweet roasted flavor to start.  Slight milky sourness.  The whole thing fades to a nice bitter hoppy finish.
a roasty black lager, goes down smooth, pours dark, bitter hops and roasted malts. pretty damn good.... reg. 5% alcohol vol.

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2010 Port Brewing Company--Midnight Sessions Lager--Oval Label--2009 Release--22 oz. Bottle--5.00% ABV--25 IBUs?  (4.25 / 5.0)  Black Lager--Thick pour.  Creamy dense lacy espresso mild head.  Opaque deep obsidian red edge hint color.  Burnt floral hop espresso front.  Rich thick burnt bitter mild creamy sweet rich smooth chocolate espresso clean lager body.  Mild hop malt spice doughy black bread end.  Sampled 9/12/2009.  $5.99 Each.

Bomber courtesy of SuzyGreenberg. Pours nearly pitch black with a thin, creamy tan head that has little retention and lacing. Aroma is subtle. Light black cherries, beautiful chocolate ganache, mocha, molassessome campfire. Taste is iced coffee, some alpha hop bitterness, fairly dry. Bit of an oily mouthfeel. Rich, easy to drink.

Bomber bottle poured into a tulip glass. The beer is as dark as an imperial stout, which through me for a loop as the beer is a lager. It was very dark with a slight white head and smelled very smoky. The taste was a very nice surprise. I didnt think I was going to like this beer but that is why we try everything. It was a very well balanced smoky porter-like flavor that light crisp and intriguing. I found it very easy and enjoyable to drink and would serve you well on a cold crisp night by the fire. It is low in alcohol at 5% but a very well done beer. Very interesting beer and a nice surprise for me.
Pours a really dark color and there is a bit of a roasty aroma to it.  After pouring it looked really good but the taste was a little thin to me.  I would prefer Full Sail Session Black.
Solid black, thick tan head. Aroma of chocolate and coffee with citrus. Pretty bold hops are accompanied by lots of dark chocolate and coffee. Finishes with roast malt and a moderate bitterness.
bomber - pours clear, dark brown with thin off-white head; aromas of brunt chocolate with a touch of cherry and smoke; drinks very smooth and sweet; chocolate, licorice, wood and smoke; good stuff

Bottle pours dark brown with a creamy khaki colored head.  Aroma is pretty subtle with notes of chocolate and extremely light coffee.  Flavor is heavy in toasted malt, with background hints of chocolate, coffee, and ash.  Overall body is a little too light for me, with a nice dry finish. Not bad, not spectacular.

Sampled at the Noogfest High Five.  Nice black pour with dark tan ring of head. Surprisingly picking up a good bit of coffee on the nose. Palate was a little on the thin side, but okay.  Reminded me of a new belgium 1554 mixed with some coffee
14th May 2008. A rich and well balanced dark lager. Easy drinking. Mellow toasted malt, subtle chocolate. Not bitter. Good carbonated bite. Dry finish.

Bomber. Big, frothy brown head, slowly diminishing. Black body. The aroma is full of chocolate and roasted malts. Notes of smoke, ash, husky grain and resin. The flavor is lightly to moderately sweet and moderately bitter. It finishes lightly sweet, moderately acidic and moderately bitter. Dry, metallic taste in the finish as well as some notes of charred wood. Medium body, watery texture and lively carbonation. Nice schwarzbier, but a little too much of the burnt malts in the finish.

Bottle.  Pours a thick black with a creamy off-white head.  Aroma is roasted malt almost all the way through, with slight grain and hops detectable.  Taste is roasted malt up front with a bit of a smoky characteristic at the end.  I found this a bit more creamy than a lager, and I detected its similarities to the wonderful Serpents Stout, but it was a solid black lager all the way through.

Poured surprisingly thick looking. Black body . Tan creamy head,  more like what Id expect from a lager. Copious amounts of roasty malts in the aroma. While it may look like a stout, flavor is clearly of a schwartzbier. Smokey malts clear in the flavors. Clean mouthfeel.  Good job!!

pure black color with with serious thick, dark brown head.  Smells like malts, with some coffee and slight roasty scents.  Taste is mainly a malt and coffee mix with some bitter/smoked undertones.  Leaves pungent smoked aftertaste.

Bottle(nice looking label).Black pour with tan head. Roasty dark malt aroma maybe even some chocolate. Hmm not your daddys lager, definitely bends the mold. Flavor is dry almost like a stout, slight coffee and chocolate flavors, nice!
22 oz from Perrys @ Livermore. Pours a thick, black with tan white head. Flavor is smoky malt and light hop notes. Dry, but just slightly sweet. Notes of chocolate and coffee.

22 oz. Very nice dark brown pour, beige head. Frothy head lasting quite a while and really sticking to the glass. Aroma is very roasty, surprising amount of coffee. Also a good amount of chocolate and some roast malt. Flavors are quite strong for such a low abv brew. Dark chocolate, cocoa, roasted malt and coffee, char. A little ashy at first, but it smoothes out as it warms. Creamy mouthfeel, this also improves with temp. Finishes like a fine stout, lots of roast and coffee. Drinkability through the roof. Would love to have this for my daily drinker. Could definetely argue this was not exactly to style, but at the end of the day, I cant help but rate it for what it is, a real good beer. 
Side note, more brewers need to focus on a quality Schwarz, it is the session beer for the dark beer folks.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: Bomber. Pours very dark brown with thick tan head. Aroma is chocolate, coffee, and roasted malt. Flavor is roasted malts, bitter chocolate, light coffee and some molasses. Mouthfeel is thinner that your would expect based on flavor. Very good sshwarzbier. Almost porter like. Good stuff.

22oz bottle shared by BeerGestapo, thanks Mike. Poured very dark brown, nearly black, with a thin tan head. Smells of chocolate, cereal, and a bit of grass. The flavor was earthy with some chocolate and a kiss of smoke. Very malty. Lasting earth and bitterness at the finish. Not like any other schwartzbier that I have ever had but really tasty anyway.

Brewed in the USA..... Pours black in color with a medium tan head that quickly dissipates. Aroma of chocolate, roasted malts and molassas. Taste of cocoa powder,earth, dark malts and and mild hops. The mouthfeel is kind of thin in body with some lingering bitterness at the finish. Overall, pretty good stuff !!! Very close to the German style Schwarzbier.

Bottle sample at Noogfest High 5 thanks to brentfeesh. Poured a brown red with a thin off-white head that left light lace. Aromas of nut, coffee, chocolate, and roast. Flavors much the same. Light to medium body.

Pours nice with a very dark brown color and garnet highlights with a tan, pillowy, average head which diminishes in a short while to a very small, lasting layer with some frothy lace.  Nose is not typical Schwarz but very pleasant, almost stoutish; notes of dark chocolate, light molasses, dark bread crusts,  lightly roasted grains, and hints at hazelnut and noble hops.  Flavor is much of the same with some dark coffee noted in there, dark bread crusts, woody/floral hops, and light molasses.  Palate is fair with a light to moderate body, nearly lively carbonation, and a dry, chalky feel. Finish is more coffee and noble hops and dry bread crust notes.  A nice, dark lager from Port but too roasty and not rich enough to be a Schwarz.  Either way, the beer only lacks due to the the dry notes in the flavor and the palate.  Not one of Port/LAs best beers but still nice.

Bomber from Sun Devil.  Thought this was a lager, so was pleasantly surprised that this pours black with a frothy beige head.  Smells predominantly of toasted malt and hazelnut.  Tastes of both with added notes of coffee grounds and smoke.  This would be awesome with BBQ.

Bomber from Ledgers.  Nice super dark brown color with auburn highlights.  Decent cap of tan foam but its a little fizzy.  Roasted malt aroma, grains, sweetened coffee, brownie mix.  Flavor is not as good, one-dimensionally roasty and a little ashy at the end.  Some extremely dark chocolate creeps into the aftertaste as well.  Body is too thin for sure.  Not bad, the aroma alone makes it better than several German schwarzbiers Ive had.

2009-06-12, bottle blind tasting at Papsøs, 6-3-6-3-11=29Black color. Papery aroma. Quite basic Stout, maybe smooth and creamy, with too much burnt malt, maybe in the end (that is even quite harsh), and too bitter.2009-05-13, draught at Nørrebro Bryghus, Copenhagen, 5-4-6-2-12=29Black color, solid big. Aroma of roasted malt and paper. Weak body, with a sharp roasted malt flavor, somehow rounded by a smooth mouthfeel, with a quite strong ending bitterness. Not bad, but without some real vibe that the Germans can give.

9/04/2008:  Port Moon Lit Sessions Lager has chocolate, cocoa, and dry coffee in the aroma.  The flavor has dry coffee that balanced the chocolate/semi-sweet chocolate sweetness.  This beer is roasty and reminds me more of a Dry Irish Stout.  It is very, very dark brown in color with a brown head, medium body, and smooth texture.  This beer definitely has some good character!
1 pint 6  fl. oz. bottle shared by alexsdad06.  Thanks Brad!  Rating #266 for this beer.

I like the style, and buying the bomber at Gordons in Watham, I was a bottle past my 12-packer for the plane. Hence an enjoyable and informative sharing with Jeff at Jaspars in Nashua. Roasty aroma, black body with permanent off-white little head, with a great drinkability, and this is 10 minutes in the fridge on a warm day. Balanced with a tad of fruitiness, and complexity in the roasted black malt.
